description: In this series we will dive into the second exam that is required for a viewer to achieve an MCSA in Windows 10. The topics will range from installation of Windows 10, post-installation configurations, applying images, various deployment tools as well as monitoring and servicing Windows 10 and more. Exam candidates are encouraged to watch both Windows 10 series for the MCSA exams.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike introduce Windows 10. They discuss how Windows operating systems have evolved over the years as well as highlighting need to know information specific to Windows 10. They explore system requirements, look at the differences between an upgrade and a clean installation, deployment options, editions and more!

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike look at numerous ways to install Windows 10. They start with a demonstration using a command line interface tool, DiskPart. She shows how to manually create a bootable USB whilst comparing the diferences between that method versus the Windows media creation tool. They also discuss methods of installation such DISM, ICD, SysPrep, WDS, and SCCM.

16

We've seen a lot happening

17

20
00:00:53.710 --> 00:00:54.800
What is a driver, right?

21
00:00:54.800 --> 00:00:59.239
A driver is going to be like an
instruction set that your operating system

22
00:00:59.239 --> 00:01:02.384

23
00:01:02.384 --> 00:01:03.617
Yeah, Mike's over there driving.

>> Yeah, I was gonna say,

[LAUGH]

the instructions allowing that

30

34
00:01:36.640 --> 00:01:40.520

00:01:40.520 --> 00:01:44.210

36
00:01:44.210 --> 00:01:48.020

our drivers to be signed.

37
00:01:48.020 --> 00:01:50.442

00:01:50.442 --> 00:01:53.604
I was gonna try out a bad joke.

00:01:53.604 --> 00:01:54.899
But just know, no.

00:01:54.899 --> 00:01:58.852

00:01:58.852 --> 00:02:03.040

42
00:02:03.040 --> 00:02:07.037

make sure that it isn't going to cause any

43
00:02:07.037 --> 00:02:09.615

the operating system.

44
00:02:09.615 --> 00:02:13.296

any kind of malware.

45
00:02:13.296 --> 00:02:15.670
>> There's no malware or
anything in there, exactly.

46
00:02:15.670 --> 00:02:19.559
>> Exactly, it's kinda crazy though,
we have to think about all this nowadays,

47
00:02:19.559 --> 00:02:20.596
but-
>> For a while,

48
00:02:20.596 --> 00:02:22.858
that was a very easy avenue attack for
the bad guys.

49
00:02:22.858 --> 00:02:25.086
Because we had to go out and
we had to find these drivers.

50
00:02:25.086 --> 00:02:28.419
So we'd do an Internet search,
you'd find some website,

51
00:02:28.419 --> 00:02:30.655
Drivers R Us, and they'd have-
>> For free.

52
00:02:30.655 --> 00:02:33.590
>> All these drivers we could download for
free, exactly.

53
00:02:33.590 --> 00:02:36.590
But what you didn't know is what
they were bundling with that driver.

54
00:02:36.590 --> 00:02:41.562
It might have been spyware,
potentially even worse types of malware.

55
00:02:41.562 --> 00:02:46.258
So by signing a driver, Microsoft
tests the driver, looks to make sure

56
00:02:46.258 --> 00:02:50.892
there's no bad content or
anything that's gonna harm your machine.

57
00:02:50.892 --> 00:02:52.900
And then they apply a digital signature.

58
00:02:52.900 --> 00:02:57.892
And what that does for us is it allows
us to verify that the driver hasn't been

59
00:02:57.892 --> 00:03:00.322
changed since Microsoft tested it.

60
00:03:00.322 --> 00:03:03.521
Because then if somebody tries to
add something after the fact or

61
00:03:03.521 --> 00:03:07.149
modify that code in that driver,
the signature will be no longer match.

62
00:03:07.149 --> 00:03:11.411
And your system will recognize that,
and say, hey look, driver is invalid.

63
00:03:11.411 --> 00:03:12.930
You need to go to get a new copy of it.

64
00:03:12.930 --> 00:03:14.350
So it's a great to keep us safe and

65
00:03:14.350 --> 00:03:17.060
protect us from people doing
bad things to our systems.

66
00:03:17.060 --> 00:03:18.020
>> Right, most definitely.

67
00:03:18.020 --> 00:03:19.870
And there are even utilities,

68
00:03:19.870 --> 00:03:23.300
we'll take a look at a little bit later,

69
00:03:23.300 --> 00:03:27.720
what he was just mentioning by utilizing

70
00:03:27.720 --> 00:03:30.180

71
00:03:30.180 --> 00:03:32.640
those driver packages
have not been modified.

72
00:03:32.640 --> 00:03:35.840
And you may hear that term driver package,

73
00:03:35.840 --> 00:03:39.180
it simply means any kind
of supporting files.

74
00:03:39.180 --> 00:03:44.200
Because usually you'll see a .inf file

75
00:03:44.200 --> 00:03:47.852
Sometimes you'll see a folder

76
00:03:47.852 --> 00:03:49.457
a driver package there.

77
00:03:49.457 --> 00:03:57.620
And Microsoft has also built upon

78
00:03:57.620 --> 00:04:02.551
And they created a variation of it,
specifically, INFs specifically for

79
00:04:02.551 --> 00:04:05.304
what they call their universal drivers.

80
00:04:05.304 --> 00:04:11.868
And that's going to be a driver that can
work across platforms as well as devices.

81
00:04:11.868 --> 00:04:14.790
Because now with the concept
of bringing your own device,

82
00:04:14.790 --> 00:04:18.020

we have mobile devices, HoloLenses.

83
00:04:18.020 --> 00:04:21.315
All kinds of cool stuff that
we can interact with, and

84
00:04:21.315 --> 00:04:25.280
those drivers should work
seamlessly across those platforms.

85
00:04:25.280 --> 00:04:28.630
>> Really simplifies the driver
development process for

86
00:04:28.630 --> 00:04:32.690
those vendors because they can now
write a single driver package.

87
00:04:32.690 --> 00:04:36.600
They don't have to have a separate one for
Windows 10 desktop,

88
00:04:36.600 --> 00:04:40.270
Windows 10 on the phone or
Windows on the phone and things like that.

89
00:04:40.270 --> 00:04:41.869
So it makes it a lot easier,
and easier for

90
00:04:41.869 --> 00:04:43.984
us cuz we've got one driver to manage for
that device.

91
00:04:43.984 --> 00:04:46.517
>> Yeah, and we were talking
about this before the show, Mike.

92
00:04:46.517 --> 00:04:50.385
Even with the advent of this Windows

93
00:04:50.385 --> 00:04:53.390

94
00:04:53.390 --> 00:04:57.478
So when you talk about drivers,

95
00:04:57.478 --> 00:04:59.305

00:05:11.681 --> 00:05:16.145

00:05:23.725 --> 00:05:28.131

00:05:28.131 --> 00:05:29.133

>> Yeah, great point.

00:05:36.399 --> 00:05:40.459

00:05:40.459 --> 00:05:43.340

110
00:05:43.340 --> 00:05:44.422
>> Exactly.

And it's not just the different

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike continue discussing recovery options. Cherokee picks up from a previous episode after reverting to a previous checkpoint. episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Daniel look an older backup method called Backup and Restore. episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Daniel take a look at some network resource sharing options. Cherokee shows where to check system configuration to verify if the system is Domain joined or part of a Workgroup. She also, demonstrates Homegroups. Although, Homegroups were removed from Windows 10 in version 1803 she covers how to set one up and connect to one preparing you for the exam.
